While it generally is quite a fun game to play, and is quite a good time waster, there are some things that put me off from really reccomending this game to people. Here are my points,  1. After clearing out pirate activity on planets (At least, I assume the skull and crossbones mean pirate activity), there isn't much else of a goal to work towards. Sure, you can buy the biggest ship and get the best guns you can find, but, that's more of a means of getting somewhere, not a goal in itself.  2. Clearing out pirate activity. Now this may sound strange when you look back on point 1, but read on. It's never really clear how you wipe out the pirates, but when you do it, you have no idea how or why the dangerzones have disappeared on the map. The only in-game goal in Destination Sol is basically clearing this out, but it seems so easy to do that it just seems that if I buy a bigger ship, they just disappear straight away.  3. Unclear main menu. There is hardly something in the way of options, you get just a few buttons for a set few resolutions, windowed or fullscreen, and sound volume from off to very high. While I am aware that this is a free game, there should've been put a little bit more thought into the options menu regardless.  4. Performance. While the game runs very smoothly on my low-end PC, there is one big glaring issue I have. -It randomly freezes up my entire computer, thus having me hard-reset the thing- I am unsure if this is the case for other people, but if it is, there need to be some patches made to fix this.   My suggestions would be to add clear objectives and goals to work towards, adding missions, making it clear how to fulfill those missions and objectives and when you have fulfilled them. Make the menu a little more clear, perhaps with some sliders, for example, for the sound volume, and patching the game so that it doesn't freeze up computers at random.    Minor nitpick: I have also run into some planet-related glitches. When tackling turrets on various planets, I often find myself warped into the terrain, unable to escape, thus having to exit the game and start a new one with my previous ship, or respawning (Which takes away some of your resources (Ammo, cash). Again, this is something that could be easily fixed.    All in all, I did find this an enjoyable game, but the lack of goals, some glitches and PC-Freezing make it less fun than it could have been.

Fun little time waster! Plays a bit like Space Pirates and Zombies.  Likes: Free! No ads or stuff to buy that I saw. Open world...go ahead and fly twords that planet with a big flashing skull on it! Planets....you can fly to planets and gravity is in effect...don't worry.. you don't take damage from flying into everything. Easy controls, use W to fly in the dirrction of your pointer. Instant mining...shoot asteroids and cash comes out...no need to refine and sell anything. Your first gun has unlimited ammo....gather lots of cash before you upgrade to a gun/ship that does need ammo.  Cons: I couldn't find anything that resembled a goal or quest. Just shoot things and get new toys. Not really a con for everyone, I just like goals. Easy controls, sort of. Apparently we can fly all over the galaxy but no one invented reverse thrusters. I keep hitting S to try to slow down....it doesn't work....get handy at spinning your ship around 180 to slow down. Ammo...somewhat limiting. Most guns take some kind of ammo that you can buy at a station or loot if your lucky. If you run out you are unable to fight until you get more. If you run out of cash and ammo...  Overall a great little game. Plays in a window or full screen. Will be my new work time waster.

The camera is so close to your ship it's hard to see if you're going to run into something. It's easy to get hung up on the ground or guard tower. When you land on a trade station, youir ship keeps trying to follow your crosshair. This can result in your ship rolling off the pad.j  Ships have no trade in value. If you buy a ship that costs $400, then decide you want a different ship that costs $300, you're out $700.  This isn't a bad game, per say. There's fun to be had here. It just comes with a lot of small annoyances. There is, without a doubt, better games of the genre you could be playing.

Long Review:  It's games like these that make me wish Steam offered more options for reviews than just recommended and not recommended. This game certainly has a lot of potential and I am excited to see what it becomes in the future, however, in it's current state it seems fairly empty to me. Destination Sol has all the mechanics it needs to become a great game, but it seems almost devoid of content at this point, I mean, it's tagged as an RPG but doesn't even have any quests (I think, I havn't played a massive amount). When this game gets some content to make it feel less empty, I will wholeheartedly recommend it, until then, I give it a 5/10, however if you're just looking for something to waste a couple minutes on, get it now, it's free, there's no reason not to, but if you are looking for an immersive gaming experience to play for hours on end, I see no reason to download this game.  Quick Review:  Pros - 1. Free. 2. Fun if you just want to blow stuff up and crash into things, and admit it, we all want to do that sometimes.  Cons- 1. Is quite empty in it's current state.  Tips For Developer: 1. ADD CONTENT! At this point Destination Sol is all mechanics and nearly nothing else. 2. Change the name, unless I'm completely missing the point of the game and I'm supposed to be going to the Sol system instead of wandering around fighting pirates, the name doesn't really fit with the rest of the game. 3. Make the ship respawn automatically when you die, it makes the game seem more polished, just a tip though, not really a major thing to fix. 4. Change the title screen, when I first got to the title screen I thought I had accidentally downloaded a horror game, it just looks like it would set the mood for a horror game better, try a sleek, futuristic look for the title screen if you change it.

Firstly, the artstyle is very nice, crisp and clean. However, the controls -while realistic- lack just that: Control. You zoom across the screen, you don't de-celerate, and you smash into objects. This wouldn't be so bad, if you could actually see where you were going. As of now, the resolution is stuck where it is, with no way to adjust it. Full-screen and windowed is the same, the screen just stretches for full-screen. Very few choices in the stores, and very few ways of making money. You're stuck to either getting into firefights with pirates, for a little money, or mining asteroids, for even less money. If you feel adventurous, you can go to the planets and fight even tougher enemies. But, with the lack of weapons, shields, ships, and everything else, you have no worthwhile things to spend that hard-won money on. Quite dissapointing right now, but hopefully the creators will be adding many more options. 3/10
